name: Dummy Deck
description: Sandbox for testing new technical phrases before migration.

cards.sideA: Pidele en el prompt que te responda en tercera persona.

sideB.text: Ask it in the prompt to reply in the third person.
Tell it to respond in the third person within the prompt.
In the prompt, ask for a response in the third person.
Ask it in the prompt to answer you in the third person.
Ask it in the prompt to respond to you in the third person.

cards.note:
When interacting with AI, [ask it to] is standard for commands.

~answer your in the third person~ is incorrect because 'your' is a possessive adjective and needs a noun. Use [answer you].

~Ask it in the prompt to response you in the third person~ and ~Ask it in the prompt to response in the third person~ are incorrect because 'response' is a noun; use the verb [respond].

~Respond you~ is incorrect because 'respond' requires the preposition 'to' when followed by an object. Use [respond to you] or simply [answer you].

cards.sideA: (Este sitio web tiene una interfaz de arrastrar y soltar muy fácil).

sideB.text: This website has a very easy drag-and-drop interface.
The drag-and-drop interface on this site is very simple.
This site offers a user-friendly drag-and-drop UI.
This website has a very easy drag-and-drop UI.

cards.note: [User-friendly] is a common way to say something is easy to use.

cards.sideA: RAG obliga a la IA a consultar una biblioteca antes de responder.

sideB.text: RAG forces the AI to check a library before answering.
RAG makes the AI look up data before responding.
With RAG, the AI must consult a knowledge base first.
RAG forces the AI to query a library before answering.

cards.note:
[Knowledge base] is the technical term for the 'biblioteca' in RAG.

~ensures the AI to check~ is grammatically incorrect. 'Ensure' should be followed by a 'that' clause. Use [forces the AI to check].

cards.sideA: RAG evita que la IA invente hechos.

sideB.text: RAG prevents the AI from making up facts.
RAG stops the AI from hallucinating facts.
RAG keeps the AI from inventing information.

cards.note:
**[176]**

[Hallucinating] is the industry term for an AI inventing facts.

~avoids the AI from making up facts~ is incorrect; 'avoid' is followed by a gerund directly. ~prevents the AI make up facts~ is missing the preposition 'from'. Use [prevents the AI from making up].

cards.sideA: Los campos del record de otro paquete estan populandose ahi

sideB.text: The fields of the record from another package are being populated there.
That's where the record fields from another package are filled.
Record fields from a different package are being populated right there.
The fields of the record from another package are populated there.

cards.note: [Fields] are the specific attributes within a [Record].

cards.sideA: ¿Esto entra dentro del alcance del proyecto?

sideB.text: Is this within the project scope?
Does this fall under the project scope?
Is this in scope for the project?
Is this included in the scope of the project?
Is this in the scope of the project?

cards.note:
**[178]**

Use [in scope] or [within scope] to confirm if a task belongs to the current plan.

cards.sideA: Me puso nervioso lo que ellos dijeron.

sideB.text: What they said made me nervous.
What they said made me feel nervous.
It made me nervous what they said.

cards.note:
**[39]**

[What they said] acts as the subject that caused the state of being [nervous].

cards.sideA: Me dio asco esa cosa.

sideB.text: That thing made me sick.
That thing made me feel sick.
That made me feel disgusted.
I got sick with that thing.

cards.note:
**[39]**

To express 'dar asco', English often uses [made me sick] or [made me feel disgusted].

~It made me sick that thing~ is unnatural word order; use [That thing made me sick].

cards.sideA: Me hizo preguntarme eso que escuche.

sideB.text: What I heard made me wonder.
It made me wonder what I heard.
That made me question things after I heard it.

cards.note:
**[39]**

[Wonder] is the base verb here. Remember that after [make], we use the base form without 'to'.

~What I heard, it made me wonder~ is redundant because [What I heard] is already the subject; you should not add [it] after it.

~It made me wonder about I heard~ is missing the relative pronoun; use [about what I heard].

cards.sideA: Me hizo quedar mal ella.

sideB.text: She made me look bad.
She made me look incompetent.
Her actions made me look bad.

cards.note:
**[39]**

[To look bad] is the standard idiom for 'quedar mal' in a social or professional sense.

~It made me look bad her~ is incorrect; the person doing the action must be the subject: [She made me look bad].

cards.sideA: Se requiere probar la función en el dispositivo real.

sideB.text: It is required to test the feature on a real device.
You are required to test the function on an actual device.
Testing the feature on the real device is required.

cards.note:
[Actual device] or [Real device] distinguish physical hardware from an emulator or simulator.

~It requires to test the feature on a real device~ is incorrect because [require] is not used as a dummy subject verb; use [It is required to test] or [Testing requires...].

cards.sideA: Quisiera que fuera más.

sideB.text: I wish it were more.
I'd like it to be more.
I want it to be more.

cards.note:
**[40]**

After 'I wish', we use the subjunctive [were] for hypothetical states.

~I'd like it to be more of it~ is invalid because it is redundant; use [I'd like more of it] or [I'd like it to be more] depending on whether you refer to quantity or quality.

cards.sideA: Me gustaria que eso fuera mejor.

sideB.text: I'd like that to be better.
I wish that were better.
I would like that to be improved.

cards.note:
Structure: [I'd like] + [object] + [to be].

~I'd like that would be better~ and ~I'd like that will be better~ are incorrect because [would like] requires the [object + to + verb] structure.

~I'd like that was better~ and ~I'd like that were better~ are incorrect because 'would like' requires the [object + to + verb] structure: [I'd like that to be better].

cards.sideA: No estarán listas para el proximo release.

sideB.text: They won't be ready for the next release.
They aren't going to be ready by the next release.
Those won't be finished for the upcoming release.

cards.note:
Use [By] or [For] to indicate a deadline.

~They won't ready~ is incorrect; 'ready' is an adjective and requires the verb [to be].

cards.sideA: La petición en postman me devolvió un 400.

sideB.text: The Postman request returned a 400.
I got a 400 error from the Postman request.
The request in Postman resulted in a 400 status code.

cards.note:
In API context, [Returned] or [Got] are standard for status codes.

~The request returned 400~ is common, but adding [a 400] or [status 400] is more precise.

cards.sideA: La carga útil se encuentra en el cuerpo de la petición.

sideB.text: The payload is in the request body.
The payload can be found within the request body.
You'll find the payload inside the request body.
The payload is found in the request body.

cards.note: [Payload] refers to the actual data transmitted in an HTTP message.

cards.sideA: La petición en postman me retornó un 200.

sideB.text: The Postman request returned a 200.
I received a 200 OK response from Postman.
The Postman call came back with a 200.

cards.note: [Came back with] is an informal but very common way to describe API responses.

cards.sideA: La petición en postman me dio una respuesta con un código de estado.

sideB.text: The Postman request gave me a response with a status code.
The request in Postman returned a response and a status code.
I got a response with a specific status code from Postman.

cards.note: [Status code] is the formal technical term for the numeric response (200, 404, 500).

cards.sideA: ¿Qué ramas fueron unidas a la rama actual?

sideB.text: Which branches were merged into the current branch?
What branches have been merged into this one?
Which branches were joined with the current branch?
Which branches were merged into the current one?

cards.note:
**[146]**

In Git, [Merged into] is the standard preposition. 

~merged to the branch~ is less common than [merged into].

~Merged in the branch~ is acceptable but [merged into] is much more precise for technical operations involving integration.

cards.sideA: Estoy solo inventando.

sideB.text: I'm just making it up.
I'm just winging it.
I am simply inventing this as I go.

cards.note:
[Making it up] means creating a story or fact. [Winging it] means doing something without preparation.

~I'm just making up~ is not valid because [make up] (meaning to invent) is a transitive phrasal verb that requires an object like [it].

cards.sideA: Dejemos en claro eso.

sideB.text: Let's make that clear.
Let's be clear about that.
Let's get that straight.
Let's make it clear.

cards.note:
**[181]**

[Get that straight] is often used when resolving a confusion or misunderstanding.

~Let's leave it clear~ is a literal translation from Spanish. In English, we use [make it clear] to express clarifying a situation.

cards.sideA: Dejemos algo en claro.

sideB.text: Let me make one thing clear.
Let's clear something up.
Let's set the record straight.
Let's make something clear.

cards.note:
**[181]**

[Clear something up] usually implies resolving a doubt.

~Let's leave something clear~ is a direct translation; use [make something clear] or [set the record straight].

cards.sideA: DBMS_OUTPUT.put_line es simplemente una sentencia print.

sideB.text: DBMS_OUTPUT.put_line is just a print statement.
DBMS_OUTPUT.put_line is simply a way to print output.
It's just a print statement, DBMS_OUTPUT.put_line.

cards.note:
A [Print statement] is the general term in any language (Console.log, System.out.println, etc.).

~Print sentence~ is incorrect. In computing, code lines are [statements], not sentences.

cards.sideA: Agregué dos campos más a la clausula SELECT.

sideB.text: I added two more fields to the SELECT clause.
I've included two additional fields in the SELECT clause.
Two more fields were added to the SELECT clause.

cards.note: [Fields] is the common term for columns within a query context.

cards.sideA: Agregué dos atributos más a la clausula SELECT.

sideB.text: I added two more attributes to the SELECT clause.
I included two more attributes in the SELECT statement.
I've added a couple of attributes to the SELECT clause.

cards.note: [Attributes] is often used in relational modeling or OO contexts to refer to data fields.

cards.sideA: Son para usarlas más adelante en otro procedimiento.

sideB.text: They are for use later in another procedure.
Those are meant to be used later in a different procedure.
They'll be used further down the line in another procedure.
They are for using later in another procedure.
They are for being used later in another procedure.

cards.note:
[Later] or [Further down the line] indicate future use.

In the phrase 'for use', [use] is a **noun**. After a preposition like 'for', you must use either a noun or a [gerund] (-ing). If you use a verb, the structure is usually [to use].

cards.sideA: Bueno… porque funciona.

sideB.text: Well... because it works.
Well, simply because it works.
I mean, it works, that's why.

cards.note: A pragmatic response in development when logic is complex but effective.

cards.sideA: Hicimos esto para hacerlo funcionar.

sideB.text: We did this to make it work.
We implemented this in order to get it working.
This was done to ensure it works.

cards.note:
[To make it work] is the standard causative structure.

We did this.

~We made this to make it work~ is redundant and uses 'make' for an action; use [did this].

 ~To make it working~ is grammatically incorrect; the causative 'make' requires the [base verb] (work).

cards.sideA: Soy una persona ahorradora.

sideB.text: I am a thrifty person.
I'm a saver.
I'm very frugal with my money.
I don't spend too much money.

cards.note: [Thrifty] and [Frugal] are positive ways to describe someone who saves.

cards.sideA: No soy alguien gastador de dinero.

sideB.text: I'm not a big spender.
I don't spend much money.
I'm not the type of person who wastes money.

cards.note: [Big spender] is the idiomatic way to describe someone who spends a lot.

cards.sideA: Perdón por el malentendido.

sideB.text: I apologize for the misunderstanding.
Sorry for the confusion.
My apologies for the mix-up.
Sorry for the misunderstanding.
Sorry for the mix-up.

cards.note: [Mix-up] is a very natural and slightly informal word for a small confusion.

cards.sideA: Oracle no te deja cambiar la password si tienes la misma anterior.

sideB.text: Oracle won't let you change the password if it's the same as the previous one.
Oracle doesn't allow you to reuse your old password.
You can't change the password in Oracle if you use the same one as before.
Oracle doesn't let you change the password if it's the same as the previous one.

cards.note: [Won't let you] is a natural way to describe system restrictions.

cards.sideA: Si tienes ‘Y’ significa ’S’, si no ‘H’.

sideB.text: If you have 'Y' it means 'S', otherwise it's 'H'.
If it's 'Y', then it stands for 'S', else it's 'H'.
'Y' means 'S'; if not, use 'H'.

cards.note:
**[179]**

[Otherwise] and [Else] are perfect for conditional logic.

cards.sideA: Una condición que no se cumpla nunca.

sideB.text: A condition that is never met.
A condition that is never fulfilled.
A condition that will never be true.

cards.note:
**[12]**

Technical term: [The condition is met] (se cumple).

~A condition that never meets~ is incorrect because 'meet' in this context is a transitive verb that requires a passive structure when the condition is the subject. Use [is never met].

cards.sideA: Eso lo usaremos más abajo.

sideB.text: We'll use that further down.
We're going to use that later on below.
That will be used further down in the code.
We'll use that below.

cards.note:
**[157]**

[Further down] is used for spatial position in a document or code file.

~We'll use it down~ is unnatural. For spatial location in files or lists, always use [below] or [further down].

cards.sideA: Eso lo usaremos abajo.

sideB.text: We'll use that below.
We will use that at the bottom.
That's for use below.

cards.note:
**[157]**

[Below] contrasts with [Above].

cards.sideA: Eso lo usaremos arriba.

sideB.text: We'll use that above.
We will use that at the top.
That's used above.

cards.note:
**[155]**

[Above] refers to preceding lines.

~We'll use that up~ is incorrect because 'up' implies direction or completion. To refer to a static position in a document or code, use [above] or [at the top].

cards.sideA: Limpié algunos comentarios.

sideB.text: I cleaned up some comments.
I've tidied up a few comments.
I removed some unnecessary comments.

cards.note: [Clean up] is the most common phrasal verb for refactoring or tidying code.

cards.sideA: Quisiera que fueran más.

sideB.text: I wish there were more.
I'd like for there to be more.
I want there to be more of them.
I'd want there to be more of them.

cards.note:
Subjunctive: [I wish there were] (not ~was~).

~I would like them to be more~ changes the meaning to 'I want them to be larger' or 'I want them to be something else'. To express existence (que hubieran), you must use the [there to be] structure.

~I would like them to be more~ is incorrect in this context because it translates to 'quisiera que fueran más [adjetivo]' (e.g., more professional) instead of referring to quantity.

~I would like them to be more of them~ is incorrect because it is redundant; the verb 'like' here requires the existential [there to be] structure to express 'que hubieran'.

cards.sideA: Me gustaría que ellos fueran mejor.

sideB.text: I'd like them to be better.
I wish they were better.
I'd want them to perform better.

cards.note: Structure: [I'd like] + [object] + [to be].

cards.sideA: La aplicación funciona inmediatamente.

sideB.text: The app works out of the box.
The application works immediately out of the box.
It works out of the box.

cards.note: In software, [out of the box] refers to features that work immediately without extra setup, configuration, or customization.

cards.sideA: El sistema ya trae seguridad integrada.

sideB.text: The system has security features out of the box.
The system provides built-in security out of the box.
Security is included out of the box.

cards.note:
Use [out of the box] to describe products that are ready to use with all necessary components included.

~The system is out of the box security already~ is incorrect word order. You can say 'The system provides [security out of the box]' or has '[out-of-the-box security]'.

cards.sideA: Necesitamos una idea original.

sideB.text: We need an out of the box idea.
We need an unconventional idea.
We need an original, out of the box solution.

cards.note:
In creative contexts, [out of the box] refers to thinking in an unconventional or innovative way to solve a problem.

~We need an idea out of the box~ is unnatural. When used figuratively, [out-of-the-box] acts as a compound adjective and should precede the noun: 'an out-of-the-box idea'.

cards.sideA: Intenta pensar de forma diferente.

sideB.text: Try to think out of the box.
Try to think outside the box.
Try to think differently and out of the box.

cards.note: While [outside the box] is the literal idiom, [out of the box] is frequently used as an adjective for the same concept.

cards.sideA: En caso que no lo hagan a tiempo

sideB.text: In case they don't do it on time.
In case they fail to do it on time.
Should they fail to do it on time.

cards.note:
After [In case], we use the present simple to talk about future possibilities. [Fail to] is a professional way to say they didn't manage to do it.

~In case they won't do it on time~ is incorrect. In English, conditional or possibility connectors like [In case] or 'If' require the [Present Simple] for the future.

cards.sideA: No quiero dañar a nadie

sideB.text: I don't want to hurt anyone.
I don't want to harm anyone.
I don't want to cause any harm to anyone.

cards.note:
Use [Hurt] or [Harm] for people. 

~I don't want to damage anyone~ is incorrect because 'damage' is used for physical objects or abstract systems.

cards.sideA: No quiero dañar ninguna dependencia

sideB.text: I don't want to break any dependencies.
I don't want to damage any dependencies.
I don't want to mess up any dependencies.

cards.note: In technical environments, we usually say [break] a dependency when a change causes it to stop working correctly.

cards.sideA: Yo quisiera que ellos fueran más. (quantity)

sideB.text: I wish there were more of them.
I wish there were more.
I'd like there to be more of them.
I'd like there to be more.

cards.note:
**[182]**

**[40]**

When asking for a higher quantity (que hubieran más), use the existential [there were] after 'wish' or [there to be] after 'like'.

cards.sideA: Yo quisiera que fuera más. (quantity)

sideB.text: I wish there were more.
I'd like there to be more.
I wish there was more.

cards.note:
**[182]**

**[40]**

[I wish there were more] is the formal subjunctive for quantity. In casual speech, 'there was' is often heard but 'there were' remains the standard.

~I'd like them to be more~ is incorrect because it implies you want the people to change (be more professional or taller), not that you want a higher number of them to exist.

cards.sideA: Yo quiero que ellos sean más. (quantity)

sideB.text: I want there to be more of them.
I'd like there to be more of them.
I want more of them.
I want there to be more.

cards.note:
**[182]**

To express the desire for more items/people to exist, use [want there to be].

cards.sideA: Yo quiero que sea más. (quantity)

sideB.text: I want there to be more.
I'd like there to be more.
I want more.

cards.note:
**[182]**

[There to be] is the standard structure to express 'that there is/are' after verbs like 'want' or 'like'.

~I want it to be more~ is incorrect because 'it' refers to a specific object changing its state (e.g., being 'more' of something like 'more red'), not to the existence of a quantity. ~I want it to be more of it~ is clunky and redundant.

cards.sideA: Quiero que haya más claridad en los requirements.

sideB.text: I want there to be more clarity in the requirements.
I'd like there to be more clarity regarding the requirements.
I want more clarity in the requirements.

cards.note:
**[182]**

[Clarity] is the noun form of 'clear'. 

~I want that there is more clarity~ is a common mistake; in English, after 'want', we use the object + infinitive structure: [I want there to be].

cards.sideA: Me gustaría que hubiera menos ruido en la oficina.

sideB.text: I'd like there to be less noise in the office.
I wish there were less noise in the office.
I'd like for there to be less noise in the office.

cards.note:
**[182]**

After 'I wish', use the subjunctive [were] even for singular/uncountable nouns like 'noise'.

[Less] is used for uncountable nouns (noise), while ~fewer~ is for countable nouns.

cards.sideA: Ellos esperan que haya algunos delays debido a la migracion.

sideB.text: They expect there to be some delays due to the migration.
They are expecting some delays because of the migration.
They expect that there will be some delays due to the migration.

cards.note:
**[182]**

[Expect there to be] follows the same pattern as 'want there to be'.

~They expect that there are delays~ is incorrect for future anticipation; use [there to be] or [there will be].

cards.sideA: El manager no quiere que haya ningún error en el reporte.

sideB.text: The manager doesn't want there to be any errors in the report.
The manager wants there to be zero errors in the report.
The manager doesn't want any errors in the report.

cards.note:
**[182]**

In negative sentences, use [any] instead of ~some~.

[Doesn't want there to be] is the correct negative structure.

cards.sideA: Nos encantaría que hubiera más recursos para este project.

sideB.text: We'd love there to be more resources for this project.
We would love for there to be more resources for this project.
We'd love to have more resources for this project.

cards.note:
**[182]**

[Would love there to be] is an emphatic way to express a wish.

~We would love that there are more resources~ is a literal translation error. Stick to the [there to be] infinitive structure.

cards.sideA: Hay problemas con acentos y signos en Frances

sideB.text: There are problems with accents and punctuation in French.
There are issues with French accents and signs.
French accents and punctuation marks are causing issues.

cards.note: [Punctuation marks] is the technical term for 'signos de puntuación'.

cards.sideA: Lo mas probable es que sea eso que dices

sideB.text: It's most likely what you're saying.
Most likely, it's what you said.
It's probably what you're talking about.

cards.note: [Most likely] indicates a high probability.

cards.sideA: Lo mas probable es que sea ese procedimiento

sideB.text: It's most likely that procedure.
That procedure is the most likely cause.
It's probably that procedure.

cards.note: When talking about software logic, we often use [most likely] to diagnose bugs.

cards.sideA: El no lo es, pero el otro lo es.

sideB.text: He isn't, but the other one is.
He's not, but the other one is.
He is not, but the other is.

cards.note: We use [the other one is] to avoid repeating the adjective or noun.

cards.sideA: El lo es, pero el otro no lo es.

sideB.text: He is, but the other one isn't.
He's the one, but the other isn't.
He is, while the other one is not.

cards.note: Observe the contrast using [but] or [while].

cards.sideA: La razón por la que no se muestra es...

sideB.text: The reason it's not being displayed is...
The reason it's not getting displayed is...
The reason why it isn't showing up is...

cards.note: [Getting displayed] is a common passive structure in UI contexts.

cards.sideA: No esta funcionando bien en ISG de EBS

sideB.text: It's not working properly in EBS ISG.
It's not working in EBS ISG.
It is not functioning correctly within EBS ISG.

cards.note: [Properly] is the professional way to say 'bien' regarding functionality.

cards.sideA: Es mas directa esta manera.

sideB.text: This way is more direct.
This manner is more direct.
Doing it this way is more direct.

cards.note: [This way] refers to the method or approach.

cards.sideA: Tenemos apodos para todo.

sideB.text: We have nicknames for everything.
We've got nicknames for everything.
Everything has a nickname here.

cards.note: [Nicknames] (apodos) is common in dev teams for servers or complex components.

cards.sideA: Se retorna un -1 como flag

sideB.text: A -1 is returned as a flag.
It returns a -1 as a flag.
The function returns -1 as a status flag.

cards.note: [Flag] is a technical term for a variable that signals a specific condition.

cards.sideA: Retornamos un cursor vacio con un -1

sideB.text: We return an empty cursor with a -1.
It returns an empty cursor along with a -1.
An empty cursor with a -1 is returned.

cards.note: [Empty cursor] is the standard DB terminology.

cards.sideA: Es mejor prevenir que lamentar

sideB.text: Better safe than sorry.
It's better to be safe than sorry.
Prevention is better than cure.

cards.note: [Better safe than sorry] is the most common idiomatic version.

cards.sideA: Es solo una costumbre que tengo

sideB.text: It's just a habit of mine.
It is just a habit I have.
That's just a habit of mine.

cards.note: [Habit of mine] is a natural way to describe personal routines.

cards.sideA: Los multiplicadores de cantidad van de 1 en 1

sideB.text: Quantity multipliers go by 1s.
Quantity multipliers increment by 1.
The quantity multipliers increase one by one.

cards.note: [Increment by] is the precise term for increasing a value by a specific amount.

cards.sideA: Cuando lo vea, te lo dire

sideB.text: When I see it, I'll tell you.
I will tell you when I see it.
Once I see it, I'll let you know.

cards.note:
**[183]**

[When I see it] uses the present simple for a future condition.

cards.sideA: Cuando yo este sin señal, podre usar un LLM local

sideB.text: When I'm without signal, I'll be able to use a local LLM.
When I have no signal, I can use a local LLM.
I'll use a local LLM when I am without signal.

cards.note:
**[183]**

[When I am without signal] corresponds to 'Cuando esté'.

cards.sideA: Cuando este en mi casa, voy a descansar

sideB.text: When I'm at home, I'm going to rest.
I will rest when I am at home.
When I get home, I'll rest.

cards.note:
**[183]**

[When I am at home] describes the state.

cards.sideA: Cuando tu estes dudando, solo preguntame.

sideB.text: When you're doubting, just ask me.
When you are in doubt, just ask me.
Just ask me when you are doubting.

cards.note:
**[183]**

[In doubt] is a very common idiom for 'dudando'.

cards.sideA: Cuando tu estes en casa, avisame.

sideB.text: When you're at home, let me know.
Let me know when you are at home.
When you get home, tell me.

cards.note:
**[183]**

[Let me know] is the standard way to say 'avísame'.
